text:
Facebook (FB), the worst performer among the FANG stocks in recent years, went 19 months without making progress amid worries over regulation and slowing revenue growth. Then the coronavirus pandemic hit, crushing the market for advertising, which accounts for 98% of total revenue. Yet FB stock may be poised to finally break out of its funk, clearing a buy point on May 19.

X

Facebook's popularity and usage exploded as social distancing made social media more indispensable. While Facebook revenue has taken a big hit, analysts think it could emerge much more powerful in a post-Covid world. So is now a good time to buy Facebook stock?

Coronvirus Kills FB Stock Bear Case

Facebook stock surged the day after management said on the April 29 first-quarter earnings call that advertising revenue had stabilized in April at a roughly flat year-over-year level. The guidance provided "huge upside" to the -5% to -10% trend Wall Street expected, noted Pivotal Research analyst Michael Levine. Levine, who had been among the biggest Facebook bears, promptly upgraded FB stock to hold from sell, hiking his price target to 225 from 167.

Flat revenue growth would have seemed unimaginably bad before Covid-19. Yet it was more than even bullish analysts could hope for in a period that coronavirus lockdowns had hit the brakes on consumer spending, grounded most air travel and cost tens of millions of jobs.

How Facebook Weathered Covid-19

So what accounts for Facebook's resilience in the face of Covid-19 economic devastation?

Return on investment: "Marketers of all sizes have more limited budgets, so they need to make every dollar work as hard as possible," COO Sheryl Sandberg said on the Q1 earnings call.

"That means measuring the value of their advertising is more important than ever, which is something our personalized ads provide. For years we have made major investments in systems and tools that enable businesses to easily understand their return on investment. In the current environment, these investments are paying off."

Shift from video advertising: Offline advertising dollars will increasingly shift to digital, JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth wrote in a post-earnings note. That could be a sizable tailwind, with the U.S. television ad market recently worth $70 billion and global TV market $200 billion. Still, some advertising dollars shifting from TV to Facebook could shift back, once live TV sports and entertainment fare returns.

Supply surge: While the coronavirus surge in usage focused on messaging, voice and video calls, more people also have used News Feed and Stories formats to to exchange updates with friends and family. Increased engagement has produced what CFO Dave Wehner called a "supply side shock," serving up more ad impressions.

Flexible auction model: The combination of a hit to demand and more supply has meant lower pricing for Facebook ads, which are purchased through ad auctions. But the extra supply is still a positive contributor.

As auto and travel-related advertising dropped off, the lower pricing met ROI needs for gaming and e-commerce advertisers that stepped up.

"We saw relative strength even then in a few categories like gaming, where you have always-on campaigns that were able to pick up some supply because the lower pricing kind of cleared at the levels that those advertisers were trying to acquire users at. So that is one of the benefits of the auction," Wehner said.

Join IBD experts as they analyze leading stocks in the coronavirus market rally on IBD Live.

Facebook Earnings

Facebook earnings for the first quarter rose 101% to $1.71 per share, missing estimates by 3 cents a share. The year-ago figure was depressed by recognition of $3 billion in legal costs tied to the eventual $5 billion Federal Trade Commission settlement. Revenue grew 18% to $17.74 billion, topping estimates. That followed 25% revenue growth in Q4, which was the slowest growth rate in more than four years.

Advertising revenue grew 17%, as the total number of ad impressions surged 39% from a year ago, while ad pricing fell 16%.

Facebook management had warned of a pronounced revenue deceleration in the fourth quarter. That partly reflected a tough comparison. In late 2018, Facebook enjoyed a revenue boost from a change in the way its ad auction operates and a ramp of advertising on Instagram Feed and Facebook Stories.

Facebook Ad Targeting Headwinds

In January, Facebook repeated its warning that headwinds related to ad targeting would slow growth this year.

Regulation that impedes third-party tracking could make it harder for Facebook to deliver relevant ads. Facebook has said that its own user-privacy initiatives also may have a negative impact on ad pricing. In addition, changes by Apple and Google may limit Facebook's ability to turn user activity on third-party websites into targeted ads.

"While we have experienced some modest impact from these headwinds to date, the majority of the impact lies in front of us," CFO Dave Wehner said on the Q4 earnings call.

Wehner said Facebook expected Q1 revenue growth "to decelerate by a low-to-mid single-digit percentage point" rate vs. Q4. But that guidance at the end of January came before the coronavirus pandemic escalated outside China.

Facebook ad targeting headwinds received much less attention in the Q1 call, but they remain an issue.

"I think this will have a broad impact on return on investment and could affect what advertisers are able to find and acquire customers effectively for their businesses," Wehner said. "They may not be able to grow as quickly as they otherwise could. And that could have a negative impact on their growth and the economy, and obviously, revenue for us."

Still, Wehner said Facebook's internal data on user activity leaves the company "relatively well positioned" to deal with an industry-wide challenge. "We've got a lot of first-party signal."

FB Stock Analysis

Facebook stock's chart signals that everything might be falling into place for a new run. FB stock has carved out a cup-with-handle base. On May 19, Facebook cleared the 215.38 buy point.

Among the big-cap winners of the decade, FB stock soared almost 600% in the five years starting July 2013. But since July 2018, Facebook investors have been on a roller-coaster ride.

Growth fears and antitrust worries triggered a brutal five-month correction in the second half of 2018. Facebook snapped back in 2019, but struggled to regain old heights. One breakout failed. The next one stalled after FB stock first cleared a cup-with-handle buy point at 198.19 on Nov. 12. A report that the Federal Trade Commission was considering an injunction to block Facebook from its plan to tightly integrate its WhatsApp and Instagram properties temporarily knocked FB stock below a buy point on Dec. 12 last year.

Then FB stock appeared to break decisively higher on Dec. 18, closing above the buy point at 202.50. That day, Deutsche Bank analyst Lloyd Walmsley touted FB stock as a top large-cap pick for 2020, citing "renewed strength" of its core Facebook app.

Momentum continued into 2020. FB stock cleared its July 2018 record on Jan. 10. On Jan. 22, FB stock rose as high as 222.75. But after its Jan. 29 earnings report, Facebook stock gapped down, falling as low as 204.75. The stock's recovery in ensuing weeks merely tracked the broad market advance, before it ran smack into the coronavirus stock market crash.

Relative Strength Improves For Facebook Stock

Here's what's new: The once-mighty FANG stock has again showed signs of outperforming the S&P 500. Following Q1 earnings, the FB stock relative strength line, the blue line in IBD charts, has approached the prior peak marked in July 2018. By comparison, even as FB stock scaled new heights in January, its RS line failed to break above its 52-week high, set in July 2019.

FB stock has other positives that also make it an important stock to watch. Facebook stock boasts an excellent 98 IBD Composite Rating. The Composite Rating combines several key fundamental and technical factors into a single score. IBD research shows all-time stock winners often have a Composite Rating of at least 95 near the start of big runs.

Facebook has a strong 96 EPS rating, on a 1-99 scale with 99 the best possible, despite massive legal costs last year, including a Q4 hit from a $550 million legal settlement with Illinois over privacy issues. Facebook's 'A' SMR rating, reflecting sales, margins and return on equity, is testament to its attractive business model.

Facebook Regulatory News

Recent reports that the Department of Justice could move ahead with an antitrust suit against Google this year are a reminder that Facebook remains in the crosshairs of regulators. The FTC and numerous state attorneys general have announced antitrust probes of Facebook. The FTC signaled it would scrutinize mergers it had previously rubber-stamped. Those likely include Facebook's Instagram and WhatsApp deals.

Facebook caught something of a break in July 2019, when the FTC approved a hefty, but manageable, $5 billion fine for its privacy abuses. The investigation sprang from disclosures that Facebook let Cambridge Analytica, a Trump campaign contractor, access users' personal data to target 2016 election messaging. Investors saw the settlement as relieving worry that the government would compel major changes in Facebook's business practices.

Facebook's foray into cryptocurrency last summer provoked an almost immediate backlash from regulators. Fed chief Jerome Powell told Congress in July that Facebook's planned Libra cryptocurrency "raises serious concerns regarding privacy, money laundering, consumer protection, financial stability." President Donald Trump said Facebook Libra may require a banking charter. Members of Congress and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin also piled on.

While Facebook's revolutionary cryptocurrency plans are on hold, it launched Facebook Pay in the U.S. on Nov. 12. The new initiative, using existing financial infrastructure and partnerships, aims to simplify and unify payment processing across Facebook and Messenger. Eventually, Facebook Pay will weave in Instagram and WhatsApp.

Other threats are still swirling. On Feb. 11, the FTC ordered Facebook and other Big Techs to submit documents related to small acquisitions from 2010 through 2019. The FTC wants to know whether small deals that escape antitrust reviews have harmed competition.

Meanwhile, the European Union is reportedly looking into allegations by rival companies that Facebook has wielded user data, rewarding partners but cutting off access to competitors.

Facebook Earnings Revival?

Investors should look for companies that are delivering sustained earnings and revenue growth of at least 25%. For many years, Facebook easily cleared that bar, driving FB stock sharply higher. Can Facebook get back to those winning ways?

For now, the coronavirus shutdown has delayed any potential reacceleration of earnings growth. In 2021, analysts currently expect EPS to jump 33.5% as the economy recovers post-Covid. Beyond that, uncertainty still clouds Facebook's future. Ad-targeting challenges and Facebook's own privacy-focused strategic vision might dent revenue growth. Meanwhile, a growing web of investigation, regulation and legislation threatens to curb Facebook's dynamism, along with that of fellow FANG stocks Amazon (AMZN) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL).

Slowing revenue growth also has raised the importance of expense growth for the bottom line.

Total expenses rose 35% in Q1, excluding legal settlement costs. On its Q1 earnings call, Facebook cut 2020 guidance of $54 billion-$59 billion in expenses to a new range of $52 billion-$56 billion. Much of the reduction reflects lower construction costs that will likely be pushed to 2021 post-Covid.

How Much Is FB Stock Worth?

Facebook stock has a market cap of just over $600 billion. That makes FB stock the fifth most valuable company on the S&P 500 index, behind Apple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT), Google stock and Amazon stock.

Watch This Key Metric

Facebook's monthly average users grew about 5% from a year ago to 659 billion in the U.S., Canada and Europe. But most user growth is now coming from the Asia-Pacific, including India, and the rest of the world. Average revenue per user (ARPU) remains key. In Q1, that metric was depressed by the coronavirus pandemic, rising 13.5% to $34.18 in the U.S. and Canada, slowing from 19% growth in Q4 and 25% in Q3.

For Facebook as a whole, ARPU rose 8.3% to $6.95, after growth of 15.6% and 19% the prior two quarters.

Most user growth is coming from lower-monetizing geographies. That's why ARPU and ad pricing in mature markets like the U.S. is the key near-term driver of results.

Facebook has initiatives to boost revenue growth in emerging markets, though they may take time to bear fruit. The company announced in April that it will invest $5.7 billion for a 10% stake in telecom firm Jio Platforms to help spur growth of India's digital economy. Facebook also is joining forces with a number of partners to boost internet connectivity in Africa via a massive undersea cable project.

Facebook also could drive revenue growth by monetizing WhatsApp, with its 2 billion users. "It's just a generally untapped opportunity so far," CEO Mark Zuckerburg said on the Q1 call. He added it will be "very exciting to build out over the coming years."

Facebook Privacy, Integration Push

Facebook is undertaking a major strategic shift that could take a few years to complete. The company announced in March that it will emphasize private, encrypted communication between individuals and small groups. The company will integrate its Messenger, WhatsApp and Instagram properties. That would let users of one site communicate privately with those on all Facebook platforms.

Facebook's strategic shift came amid executive departures, suggesting internal dissension. Those plans would be jeopardized if the FTC intervenes to enjoin Facebook from completing the integration, as it is reported to be considering. Integration could make it hard for regulators to break up Facebook, splitting off WhatsApp and Instagram.

Facebook's big privacy vision is linked with its focus on payments, via Facebook Pay and development of its own cryptocurrency, Libra. Analysts think Facebook aims to do what Tencent (TCEHY) has done in China with its messaging app WeChat, providing a go-to communications and payments platform for billions of users.

President Trump criticized Facebook's crypto plans, suggesting the company may need a banking charter to proceed. Fed chief Jerome Powell's comments cast doubt on the feasibility of a Libra launch in 2020. The Fed and European Central Bank have expressed worry that Libra could complicate their ability to effectively conduct monetary policy.

Several initial Libra partners have dropped out, including Visa (V), Mastercard (MA) and PayPal (PYPL).

Facebook Pay may offer a way to achieve many of the same goals as Libra without the controversy.

FB Stock Is A Buy

Going into 2020, Wall Street analysts were mostly bullish, betting on stronger Facebook earnings growth. They think this FANG stock still has a long growth runway and provides value to advertisers. Tasty margins might even mean a dividend in Facebook's not-so-distant future. While there are still questions about how Facebook will perform post-Covid, it has proved its mettle during an unprecedented economic downturn.

Investors also can't ignore regulatory and political risks, though they could take years to play out. Facebook and its Big Tech peers face possible remedies ranging from new privacy safeguards to outright breakups. Still, regulation also could be fuel for the stock: the longer Facebook goes without game-changing regulation, the more fully it will be able to execute its grand vision.

For now, Facebook has proven doubters wrong. The FB stock chart shows rising relative strength, shares are just above a buy point and the stock market is in a confirmed uptrend, according to IBD's daily The Big Picture column.

Bottom line: Facebook stock is a buy.

<article class="clearfix post-4459143 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-research tag-evergreen tag-facebook-stock-news tag-fang-stock-news tag-stocks-to-buy-or-sell prim_stock_symbol-fb prim_stock_symbol-googl article_type-staffarticle distribution_rights-distribute">

<ul class="post-categories">
<li><a href="https://www.investors.com/category/research/" rel="category tag">Research</a></li></ul> <h1 class="header1">
FB Stock Breaks Out; Facebook Has Never Been More Popular Than During Coronavirus Crisis	</h1>
<div class="featured-post-image-container"></div>
<div class="addtoany_share_save_container addtoany_content_top row">
<div class="share">
<div class="a2a_kit a2a_kit_size_25 addtoany_list" data-a2a-url="https://www.investors.com/research/fb-stock-buy-now-facebook-stock/" data-a2a-title="FB Stock Breaks Out; Facebook Has Never Been More Popular Than During Coronavirus Crisis"><a class="a2a_button_facebook" href="https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/facebook?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.investors.com%2Fresearch%2Ffb-stock-buy-now-facebook-stock%2F&linkname=FB%20Stock%20Breaks%20Out%3B%20Facebook%20Has%20Never%20Been%20More%20Popular%20Than%20During%20Coronavirus%20Crisis" title="Facebook" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank"><img src="/wp-content/themes/ibd/dist/images/share-icons/facebook.png" width="25" height="25" alt="Facebook"></a><a class="a2a_button_twitter" href="https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/twitter?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.investors.com%2Fresearch%2Ffb-stock-buy-now-facebook-stock%2F&linkname=FB%20Stock%20Breaks%20Out%3B%20Facebook%20Has%20Never%20Been%20More%20Popular%20Than%20During%20Coronavirus%20Crisis" title="Twitter" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank"><img src="/wp-content/themes/ibd/dist/images/share-icons/twitter.png" width="25" height="25" alt="Twitter"></a><a class="a2a_button_linkedin" href="https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/linkedin?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.investors.com%2Fresearch%2Ffb-stock-buy-now-facebook-stock%2F&linkname=FB%20Stock%20Breaks%20Out%3B%20Facebook%20Has%20Never%20Been%20More%20Popular%20Than%20During%20Coronavirus%20Crisis" title="LinkedIn" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank"><img src="/wp-content/themes/ibd/dist/images/share-icons/linkedin.png" width="25" height="25" alt="LinkedIn"></a><a class="a2a_dd addtoany_share_save addtoany_share" href="https://www.addtoany.com/share"><img src="/wp-content/themes/ibd/dist/images/share-icons/email.png" alt="Share"></a></div> <a class="reprints-button sharing" href="https://www.ibdlicensing.com" target="_blank">Licensing</a>
</div>
<ul class="post-meta">
<li><span class="authors-links"><a href="https://www.investors.com/author/grahamj/" title="Posts by JED GRAHAM" class="author url fn" rel="author">JED GRAHAM</a></span></li>
<li class="post-time">04:23 PM ET 05/19/2020</li>
</ul>
</div>
</header>
<div class="single-post-content post-content drop-cap">
<p><strong>Facebook</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=FB' target='_blank'>FB</a>), the worst performer among the <a href="https://www.investors.com/news/technology/what-are-fang-stocks-faang-stocks/">FANG stocks</a> in recent years, went 19 months without making progress amid worries over regulation and slowing revenue growth. Then the coronavirus pandemic hit, crushing the market for advertising, which accounts for 98% of total revenue. Yet FB stock may be poised to finally break out of its funk, clearing a buy point on May 19.</p>
<span>
<span style="width:50%;" class="video-player-container vms-left">
<span class="shortcode-video" vid-id="5515840" vid-dom-id="5515840-5ec4940ee3e8b" vid-top="false" vid-repeat="1" vid-width="50" vid-url="https://content.jwplatform.com/manifests/83FKXzbR.m3u8" data-captions="" vid-name="Facebook Stock In A Buy Zone; Is This FANG Stock A Good Buy?" vid-cat="IBD Videos" vid-date="02/18/2020" vid-image="https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/83FKXzbR-640x360.jpg" vid-authors="IBD VIDEOS">
<span class="close-mini-vid">X</span>
<span id="shortcode-video-player-5515840-5ec4940ee3e8b" class="ready-to-load"></span>
</span>
</span>
</span><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","name":"Facebook Stock In A Buy Zone; Is This FANG Stock A Good Buy?","description":"Facebook stock soared from 2013 to 2018, Facebook Pay is operational, and their user count is up to 2.2 billion across all platforms. This FANG stock is a good pick for investors yet again, despite opposition from growth moderates, regulators and politicians.","thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/www.investors.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/83FKXzbR-640x360.jpg","contentUrl":"https:\/\/content.jwplatform.com\/manifests\/83FKXzbR.m3u8","uploadDate":"2020-02-18T07:28:45+0000","duration":"PT101.15S","author":"IBD VIDEOS","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Investor's Business Daily","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/www.investors.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/09\/ibd-logo.png"},"url":"https:\/\/www.investors.com"},"keywords":""}</script>
<p>Facebook's popularity and usage exploded as social distancing made social media more indispensable. While Facebook revenue has taken a big hit, analysts think it could emerge much more powerful in a post-Covid world. So is now a good time to buy Facebook stock?</p>
<h2>Coronvirus Kills FB Stock Bear Case</h2>
<p>Facebook stock surged the day after management said on the April 29 first-quarter earnings call that advertising revenue had stabilized in April at a roughly flat year-over-year level. The guidance provided "huge upside" to the -5% to -10% trend Wall Street expected, noted Pivotal Research analyst Michael Levine. Levine, who had been among the biggest Facebook bears, promptly upgraded FB stock to hold from sell, hiking his price target to 225 from 167.</p>
<p>Flat revenue growth would have seemed unimaginably bad before Covid-19. Yet it was more than even bullish analysts could hope for in a period that coronavirus lockdowns had hit the brakes on consumer spending, grounded most air travel and cost tens of millions of jobs.</p>
<h2>How Facebook Weathered Covid-19</h2>
<p>So what accounts for Facebook's resilience in the face of Covid-19 economic devastation?</p>
<p>Return on investment: "Marketers of all sizes have more limited budgets, so they need to make every dollar work as hard as possible," COO Sheryl Sandberg said on the Q1 earnings call.</p>
<p>"That means measuring the value of their advertising is more important than ever, which is something our personalized ads provide. For years we have made major investments in systems and tools that enable businesses to easily understand their return on investment. In the current environment, these investments are paying off."</p>
<p>Shift from video advertising: Offline advertising dollars will increasingly shift to digital, JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth wrote in a post-earnings note. That could be a sizable tailwind, with the U.S. television ad market recently worth $70 billion and global TV market $200 billion. Still, some advertising dollars shifting from TV to Facebook could shift back, once live TV sports and entertainment fare returns.</p>
<p>Supply surge: While the coronavirus surge in usage focused on messaging, voice and video calls, more people also have used News Feed and Stories formats to to exchange updates with friends and family. Increased engagement has produced what CFO Dave Wehner called a "supply side shock," serving up more ad impressions.</p>
<p>Flexible auction model: The combination of a hit to demand and more supply has meant lower pricing for Facebook ads, which are purchased through ad auctions. But the extra supply is still a positive contributor.</p>
<p>As auto and travel-related advertising dropped off, the lower pricing met ROI needs for gaming and e-commerce advertisers that stepped up.</p>
<p>"We saw relative strength even then in a few categories like gaming, where you have always-on campaigns that were able to pick up some supply because the lower pricing kind of cleared at the levels that those advertisers were trying to acquire users at. So that is one of the benefits of the auction," Wehner said.</p>
<hr />
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="https://shop.investors.com/offer/splashresponsive.aspx?id=IBD-Live&src=A00433A&refcode=pdsoc%7Cggl%7Cibdlive%7C2019%7C11%7Cibdlive%7Cna%7C985802&intcode=invstcntnartcls|cms|ibdlive|2019|11|ibdlive|na|682843"><strong>Join IBD experts as they analyze leading stocks in the coronavirus market rally on IBD Live.</strong></a></p>
<hr />
<h2>Facebook Earnings</h2>
<p>Facebook earnings for the first quarter rose 101% to $1.71 per share, missing estimates by 3 cents a share. The year-ago figure was depressed by recognition of $3 billion in legal costs tied to the eventual $5 billion Federal Trade Commission settlement. Revenue grew 18% to $17.74 billion, topping estimates. That followed 25% revenue growth in Q4, which was the slowest growth rate in more than four years.</p>
<p>Advertising revenue grew 17%, as the total number of ad impressions surged 39% from a year ago, while ad pricing fell 16%.</p>
<p>Facebook management had warned of a pronounced revenue deceleration in the fourth quarter. That partly reflected a tough comparison. In late 2018, Facebook enjoyed a revenue boost from a change in the way its ad auction operates and a ramp of advertising on Instagram Feed and Facebook Stories.</p>

Take a free trial!</strong></p>
<hr />
<h2>Facebook Ad Targeting Headwinds</h2>
<p>In January, Facebook repeated its warning that headwinds related to ad targeting would slow growth this year.</p>
<p>Regulation that impedes third-party tracking could make it harder for Facebook to deliver relevant ads. Facebook has said that its own user-privacy initiatives also may have a negative impact on ad pricing. In addition, changes by Apple and Google may limit Facebook's ability to turn user activity on third-party websites into targeted ads.</p>
<p>"While we have experienced some modest impact from these headwinds to date, the majority of the impact lies in front of us," CFO Dave Wehner said on the Q4 earnings call.</p>
<p>Wehner said Facebook expected Q1 revenue growth "to decelerate by a low-to-mid single-digit percentage point" rate vs. Q4. But that guidance at the end of January came before the coronavirus pandemic escalated outside China.</p>
<p>Facebook ad targeting headwinds received much less attention in the Q1 call, but they remain an issue.</p>
<p>"I think this will have a broad impact on return on investment and could affect what advertisers are able to find and acquire customers effectively for their businesses," Wehner said. "They may not be able to grow as quickly as they otherwise could. And that could have a negative impact on their growth and the economy, and obviously, revenue for us."</p>
<p>Still, Wehner said Facebook's internal data on user activity leaves the company "relatively well positioned" to deal with an industry-wide challenge. "We've got a lot of first-party signal."</p>
<h2>FB Stock Analysis</h2>
<p>Facebook stock's chart signals that everything might be falling into place for a new run. FB stock has carved out a <a href="https://www.investors.com/how-to-invest/investors-corner/the-basics-how-to-analyze-a-stocks-cup-with-handle/">cup-with-handle base</a>. On May 19, Facebook cleared the 215.38 buy point.</p>
<p>Among the big-cap winners of the decade, FB stock soared almost 600% in the five years starting July 2013. But since July 2018, Facebook investors have been on a roller-coaster ride.</p>
<p>Growth fears and antitrust worries triggered a brutal five-month correction in the second half of 2018. Facebook snapped back in 2019, but struggled to regain old heights. One breakout failed. The next one stalled after FB stock first cleared a cup-with-handle buy point at 198.19 on Nov. 12. A report that the Federal Trade Commission was considering an injunction to block Facebook from its plan to tightly integrate its WhatsApp and Instagram properties temporarily knocked FB stock below a buy point on Dec. 12 last year.</p>
<p>Then FB stock appeared to break decisively higher on Dec. 18, closing above the buy point at 202.50. That day, Deutsche Bank analyst Lloyd Walmsley touted FB stock as a top large-cap pick for 2020, citing "renewed strength" of its core Facebook app.</p>
<p>Momentum continued into 2020. FB stock cleared its July 2018 record on Jan. 10. On Jan. 22, FB stock rose as high as 222.75. But after its Jan. 29 earnings report, Facebook stock gapped down, falling as low as 204.75. The stock's recovery in ensuing weeks merely tracked the broad market advance, before it ran smack into the coronavirus stock market crash.</p>
<div class="small-12 columns "><div class='ibd-chart-container' style='position:relative;width:100%;height:462px;overflow:hidden;'><iframe class='ibd-chart-frame' style='position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:99.9%;height:100%;' frameborder='0' src='https://research.investors.com/ibdchartswp.aspx?cht=pvc&type=daily&symbol=fb'></iframe></div></div>
<h2>Relative Strength Improves For Facebook Stock</h2>
<p>Here's what's new: The once-mighty FANG stock has again showed signs of outperforming the S&P 500. Following Q1 earnings, the FB stock <a href="https://www.investors.com/how-to-invest/investors-corner/a-stock-breakout-specialty-tool-the-relative-strength-line/">relative strength line</a>, the blue line in IBD charts, has approached the prior peak marked in July 2018. By comparison, even as FB stock scaled new heights in January, its RS line failed to break above its 52-week high, set in July 2019.</p>
<p>FB stock has other positives that also make it an important stock to watch. Facebook stock boasts an excellent 98 <a href="https://www.investors.com/how-to-invest/investors-corner/how-to-research-growth-stocks/">IBD Composite Rating</a>. The Composite Rating combines several key fundamental and technical factors into a single score. IBD research shows all-time stock winners often have a Composite Rating of at least 95 near the start of big runs.</p>
<p>Facebook has a strong 96 EPS rating, on a 1-99 scale with 99 the best possible, despite massive legal costs last year, including a Q4 hit from a $550 million legal settlement with Illinois over privacy issues. Facebook's 'A' SMR rating, reflecting sales, margins and return on equity, is testament to its attractive business model.</p>
<div class="small-12 columns "><div class='ibd-chart-container' style='position:relative;width:100%;height:462px;overflow:hidden;'><iframe class='ibd-chart-frame' style='position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:99.9%;height:100%;' frameborder='0' src='https://research.investors.com/ibdchartswp.aspx?cht=pvc&type=weekly&symbol=fb'></iframe></div></div>
<h2>Facebook Regulatory News</h2>
<p>Recent reports that the Department of Justice could move ahead with an antitrust suit against Google this year are a reminder that Facebook remains in the crosshairs of regulators. The FTC and numerous state attorneys general have announced antitrust probes of Facebook. The FTC signaled it would scrutinize mergers it had previously rubber-stamped. Those likely include Facebook's Instagram and WhatsApp deals.</p>
<p>Facebook caught something of a break in July 2019, when the FTC approved a hefty, but manageable, $5 billion fine for its privacy abuses. The investigation sprang from disclosures that Facebook let Cambridge Analytica, a Trump campaign contractor, access users' personal data to target 2016 election messaging. Investors saw the settlement as relieving worry that the government would compel major changes in Facebook's business practices.</p>
<p>Facebook's foray into cryptocurrency last summer provoked an almost immediate backlash from regulators. Fed chief Jerome Powell told Congress in July that Facebook's planned Libra cryptocurrency "raises serious concerns regarding privacy, money laundering, consumer protection, financial stability." President Donald Trump said Facebook Libra may require a banking charter. Members of Congress and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin also piled on.</p>
<p>While Facebook's revolutionary cryptocurrency plans are on hold, it launched Facebook Pay in the U.S. on Nov. 12. The new initiative, using existing financial infrastructure and partnerships, aims to simplify and unify payment processing across Facebook and Messenger. Eventually, Facebook Pay will weave in Instagram and WhatsApp.</p>
<p>Other threats are still swirling. On Feb. 11, the FTC ordered Facebook and other Big Techs to submit documents related to small acquisitions from 2010 through 2019. The FTC wants to know whether small deals that escape antitrust reviews have harmed competition.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, the European Union is reportedly looking into allegations by rival companies that Facebook has wielded user data, rewarding partners but cutting off access to competitors.</p>

<h2>Facebook Earnings Revival?</h2>
<p>Investors should look for companies that are delivering sustained earnings and revenue growth of at least 25%. For many years, Facebook easily cleared that bar, driving FB stock sharply higher. Can Facebook get back to those winning ways?</p>
<p>For now, the coronavirus shutdown has delayed any potential reacceleration of earnings growth. In 2021, analysts currently expect EPS to jump 33.5% as the economy recovers post-Covid. Beyond that, uncertainty still clouds Facebook's future. Ad-targeting challenges and Facebook's own privacy-focused strategic vision might dent revenue growth. Meanwhile, a growing web of investigation, regulation and legislation threatens to curb Facebook's dynamism, along with that of fellow FANG stocks <strong>Amazon</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=AMZN' target='_blank'>AMZN</a>) and Google parent <strong>Alphabet</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=GOOGL' target='_blank'>GOOGL</a>).</p>
<p>Slowing revenue growth also has raised the importance of expense growth for the bottom line.</p>
<p>Total expenses rose 35% in Q1, excluding legal settlement costs. On its Q1 earnings call, Facebook cut 2020 guidance of $54 billion-$59 billion in expenses to a new range of $52 billion-$56 billion. Much of the reduction reflects lower construction costs that will likely be pushed to 2021 post-Covid.</p>
<h2>How Much Is FB Stock Worth?</h2>
<p>Facebook stock has a market cap of just over $600 billion. That makes FB stock the fifth most valuable company on the S&P 500 index, behind <strong>Apple</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=AAPL' target='_blank'>AAPL</a>), <strong>Microsoft</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=MSFT' target='_blank'>MSFT</a>), Google stock and Amazon stock.</p>
<h2>Watch This Key Metric</h2>
<p>Facebook's monthly average users grew about 5% from a year ago to 659 billion in the U.S., Canada and Europe. But most user growth is now coming from the Asia-Pacific, including India, and the rest of the world. Average revenue per user (ARPU) remains key. In Q1, that metric was depressed by the coronavirus pandemic, rising 13.5% to $34.18 in the U.S. and Canada, slowing from 19% growth in Q4 and 25% in Q3.</p>
<p>For Facebook as a whole, ARPU rose 8.3% to $6.95, after growth of 15.6% and 19% the prior two quarters.</p>
<p>Most user growth is coming from lower-monetizing geographies. That's why ARPU and ad pricing in mature markets like the U.S. is the key near-term driver of results.</p>
<p>Facebook has initiatives to boost revenue growth in emerging markets, though they may take time to bear fruit. The company announced in April that it will invest $5.7 billion for a 10% stake in telecom firm Jio Platforms to help spur growth of India's digital economy. Facebook also is joining forces with a number of partners to boost internet connectivity in Africa via a massive undersea cable project.</p>
<p>Facebook also could drive revenue growth by monetizing WhatsApp, with its 2 billion users. "It's just a generally untapped opportunity so far," CEO Mark Zuckerburg said on the Q1 call. He added it will be "very exciting to build out over the coming years."</p>
<h2>Facebook Privacy, Integration Push</h2>
<p>Facebook is undertaking a major strategic shift that could take a few years to complete. The company announced in March that it will emphasize private, encrypted communication between individuals and small groups. The company will integrate its Messenger, WhatsApp and Instagram properties. That would let users of one site communicate privately with those on all Facebook platforms.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.investors.com/news/technology/facebook-stock-executive-officers-resigns/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Facebook's strategic shift came amid executive departures</a>, suggesting internal dissension. Those plans would be jeopardized if the FTC intervenes to enjoin Facebook from completing the integration, as it is reported to be considering. Integration could make it hard for regulators to break up Facebook, splitting off WhatsApp and Instagram.</p>
<p>Facebook's big privacy vision is linked with its focus on payments, via Facebook Pay and development of its own cryptocurrency, Libra. Analysts think Facebook aims to do what <strong>Tencent</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=TCEHY' target='_blank'>TCEHY</a>) has done in China with its messaging app WeChat, providing a go-to communications and payments platform for billions of users.</p>
<p>President Trump criticized Facebook's crypto plans, suggesting the company may need a banking charter to proceed. Fed chief Jerome Powell's comments cast doubt on the feasibility of a Libra launch in 2020. The Fed and European Central Bank have expressed worry that Libra could complicate their ability to effectively conduct monetary policy.</p>
<p>Several initial Libra partners have dropped out, including <strong>Visa</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=V' target='_blank'>V</a>), <strong>Mastercard</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=MA' target='_blank'>MA</a>) and <strong>PayPal</strong> (<a class='ticker' href='https://research.investors.com/quote.aspx?symbol=PYPL' target='_blank'>PYPL</a>).</p>
<p>Facebook Pay may offer a way to achieve many of the same goals as Libra without the controversy.</p>
<h2>FB Stock Is A Buy</h2>
<p>Going into 2020, Wall Street analysts were mostly bullish, betting on stronger Facebook earnings growth. They think this FANG stock still has a long growth runway and provides value to advertisers. Tasty margins might even mean a dividend in Facebook's not-so-distant future. While there are still questions about how Facebook will perform post-Covid, it has proved its mettle during an unprecedented economic downturn.</p>
<p>Investors also can't ignore regulatory and political risks, though they could take years to play out. Facebook and its Big Tech peers face possible remedies ranging from new privacy safeguards to outright breakups. Still, regulation also could be fuel for the stock: the longer Facebook goes without game-changing regulation, the more fully it will be able to execute its grand vision.</p>
<p>For now, Facebook has proven doubters wrong. The FB stock chart shows rising relative strength, shares are just above a buy point and the stock market is in a confirmed uptrend, according to IBD's daily <a href="https://www.investors.com/category/market-trend/the-big-picture/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Big Picture</a> column.</p>
<p>Bottom line: Facebook stock is a buy.</p>
